title: 'We haven't a clue what Brexit means' | Leicester Mercury
text:
'We haven't a clue what Brexit means' By Leicester Mercury | Posted: June 07, 2016 Tim Horrocks 'We haven't a clue what Brexit means' X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
Leicester's services community has voiced its concerns over the uncertainty surrounding the EU referendum. 
Some have started providing clients with financial services they hope won't be affected whichever way the vote goes. 
Others have said, in the short term at least, they will benefit from the potentially costly changes to our laws that could follow a break. 
While others belive that in the long-term, Britain will be stronger out. 
It comes after a recent Institute of Directors survey found East Midlands business leaders were split around six to three in favour of remaining in the European Union. 
However, three-quarters thought the EU needed reform to prevent economic decline . 
Another survey, by East Midlands Chamber of Commerce, said almost half of firms had only a "limited understanding" of the business implications of the UK leaving the EU. 
Tim Horrocks is head of the Leicester office of investment management business Quilter Cheviot, in New Walk, and said they were looking at new products as a result, to mitigate risks. 
He said: "Where appropriate for our client needs and as the EU referendum opinion polls have become closer, we have been moving up to 5 per cent of a client's portfolio into US dollars through the purchase of short dated US Treasury bonds." 
David Heys is the chief executive of law firm Lawson-West Commercial, in Leicester. He said: "It's the uncertainty that concerns me. We haven't got a clue what Brexit will mean . 
"The economy is stalling a little bit and you can talk your way into difficulty. Growth estimates for next year are not high and Brexit is not going to help. 
"But it's going to be fantastic for the legal profession in the short-term if we vote out, because the complexities of extricating ourselves will be horrendous." 
Duncan Green, below, left, managing partner of national building consultancy Pick Everard, in Charles Street, Leicester, said they were experts in complying with EU procurement rules, so a Brexit vote would be an obvious setback . 
He said: "I think we [the UK] have done well out of the EU and have had a stable economy, and I know we've been through a recession, but I don't think that was as deep as it might have been. 
"I don't think there are any clubs where you would be treated better if you left than if you stayed in. 
"I think the UK contributes well to Europe." 
However, Chris Darlington, partner at accountants Mazars' Leicester office, said: "The problem for me is that people will vote to stay in because they feel it's better to stick with what they know. 
Real estate lawyer Richard Osborn, partner and regional office head at Weightmans, Leicester, said he had not seen many "sound, solid" arguments for leaving. 
He said: "We are neutral as a business, but I'm firmly in the remain camp. 
"I think it will cause a lot of uncertainty for a long time. 
"I think property investment generally has gone a little lukewarn."
